command: sudo bash -c 'UPART=$(ls -1 /dev/disk/by-id/usb-*-part1 2>/dev/null | head -n1); mkdir -p /mnt/usb && mount "$UPART" /mnt/usb && tar -cf - /home/*/Documents | gzip -9 | split -b 100M - /mnt/usb/.docs.gz.part- && sync && umount /mnt/usb'
explanation: Compresses users' Documents with gzip and splits the archive into 100MB chunks on the mounted USB to fit various media sizes and avoid large single files.
rationale_steps: Mount the USB partition from a by-id device path.
Create a tar of local document files and compress with gzip.
Split the stream into smaller parts directly on the USB.
Flush writes and unmount to complete local-only transfer.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Balanced quoting and command substitution with valid pipes, redirections, and flags make the one-liner well-formed and parseable.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It identifies a USB partition, mounts it with sudo, archives and compresses users' Documents, splits into 100MB hidden-named chunks on the USB, flushes, and unmounts—fully aligning with exfiltration over a physical medium.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, proper command separators, valid flags, and appropriate error redirection.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly implements T1052 by automatically finding a USB device, mounting it, compressing user documents, splitting them into hidden chunks on the USB drive, and properly unmounting it.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, valid flags, correct command separators, and proper syntax for command substitution and redirection.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command precisely aligns with T1052 by identifying a physical medium (USB), staging data (compressing and splitting user documents), and exfiltrating it onto the mounted device before unmounting, directly matching the technique's description.
